body:
Yup, you can do this. The model weights learned from a patch model can be loaded into a full model, since the weights belong to the convolution layers only.

So you can:
1. create and train model with patches --> save weights
2. create model for full image and load saved weights from patch model.

Of course, I'm not certain how well this will work since training and testing are slightly different, but it's certainly doable.

@jeanyves-yang: Do you solve the problem? if you use the image-patches, such as 32x32x32 or 64x64x64 then how do you achive the final moved image? As far as I know, it should be used over-lapping between patches with stride >1 to construct the whole prediction from the prediction of patches.

@John1231983 For training, it did not matter, I trained with overlapping patches. For prediction/inference, I performed it on the whole image (I thought reconstructing from patches was slower than just infering on the whole image).

@jeanyves-yang @John1231983 yup this sounds good to me -- at training, you can just load the weights into a model that's the full size.

I would be careful about training with patches, since having the correct deformation at the edges of the images is hard in that case.

@John1231983 The weights are all convolutional, so they are invariant to model size. True, they learned on patches, but conceptually they learned something that is spatially invariant

So you can do something like 
```
model_64_patches = cvpr_2018([64,64,64], ...)
model_64_patches.fit(patches)

model_256 = cvpr_2018([256,256,256], ...)
model_256.set_weights(model_64_patches.get_weights())
model_256.predict(...)  # registration of full image)
```

Thanks. I tried it and the result is too bad.

For question about edge
>I would be careful about training with patches, since having the correct deformation at the edges of the images is hard in that case.

Assume that we have two crops (left:moving, right: fixed). So, we can see that in the boundary of the crop region (top-left, top-bottom....), these pixels may not move because it is in outer regions. It means the deformation field at the position will learn to zero. TO solve it, do you think we need to add zero paddings to the crop images, so that the foreground region can expanding...
![Screenshot from 2019-09-04 12-59-35](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24875971/64275622-09124a80-cf14-11e9-9162-dfd2ba59a234.png)

Updated: Sorry, we can use weight train from 64x64x64 to predict deformation of 256x256x256. It worked. But the boundary still is an issue

@jeanyves-yang  and @adalca : I have found a paper that used the patch-based approach for image registration. Actually, it is very similar your network, just used patches instead of full image. And it used ground-truth deformation (I guess from ants)
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1361841519300283

In this paper, he mentioned that he downed image resolution from 64x64x64 to 24x24x24 and the prediction deformation is in the downing resolution 24x24x24. However, it is not clear how he can compute the spatial loss between moving and target image because the patch size is 64x64x64, while deformation field is 24x24x24. Let's me know if you find the answer

For testing, he combined predicted 24x24x24 deformation field without padding.

sorry, i probably wasn't clear

I was saying above how you *can* do it, now how you *should* do it :) In general, I don't think you should train on patches! there are all sorts of issues. Padding won't help, then the network will try to enforce the edge between the image and the background to fit the edge in the second image, which is bad. 

The main solution I see is to have the loss operate only over the center of the patch. e.g. if the patch is 64^3, then have the loss operate only over the center 32^3 or 16^3.

But the main alternative is to have the biggest volume your GPU memory can handle, this has always worked best for us.
